Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Novel Tighter Relaxations for Complementarity Constraints with Applications to Nonlinear and Bilevel Programming

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
This collaborative research award provides funding for the development of new and stronger techniques for the solution of optimization problems with complementarity constraints to global optimality. Complementarity problems are pervasive in business, engineering, and economics, since complementarity conditions arise in optimality conditions for nonlinear programs and in models of equilibria. Algorithms for complementarity problems have until recently focused on feasibility problems by employing local optimization techniques. This project focuses on the development of convex relaxations for these problems, with the goal of incorporating them into branch-and-bound algorithms for global optimization. The research is aimed at deriving procedures that (i) exploit the combinatorial and disjunctive structure of complementarity constraints, (ii) focus on relaxations with a provable guarantee of strength, and (iii) target problems in which some of the constraints (besides complementarities) are nonlinear. The benefits of relaxation techniques will be studied relative to mature implementations of global optimization algorithms.

If successful, the new relaxations developed with this research, along with factorable decomposition and separation techniques, will advance the state of the art in the global optimization of complementarity programs, bringing many practically relevant problems within the range of tractability. Because complementarity constraints arise in equilibrium analyses of supply and demand, adversarial relationships between strategically interacting entities, traffic equilibria, and in the analyses of multistage optimization problems, this research could lead to improved efficiencies in various sectors of the economy. Further, since bilevel programs have numerous applications in defense planning, including interdiction and protection of critical infrastructure, this research could impact positively various areas of national defense. From an educational perspective, related material will be incorporated into undergraduate and graduate education and doctoral students will be trained in relevant technologies including integer programming and global optimization. In addition, a website will be designed to disseminate prototype implementations and problem data sets.

POR.DRECONTENT:
For the last few decades, optimization models have been used to identify the best way to design and to operate systems. Although some classes of optimization can be solved efficiently with existing technology, the solution of others remains a challenge. With this proposal, we introduced new tools for the solution of a subclass of these problems, namely those containing complementarity or, more generally, cardinality constraints. 


Complementarity constraints - expressing that the product of two quantities is equal to zero - are pervasive in business, engineering, and economics models. They are used to capture equilibria between supply and demand, adversarial relationships between entities, and traffic equilibria. In a more general form, they appear as cardinality constraints, which stipulate that no more than a specified number of terms can be nonzero in a given product. Cardinality constraints arise in a myriad of practical applications. In particular, they are becoming increasingly important in parameter estimation problems because sparse solutions are easier to interpret and avoid overfitting. 


In this research, we focused on the structural analysis of problems involving these types of constraints, and in particular, on how to produce structured approximations that can be solved efficiently. We followed a four-pronged approach. First, we studied the structure of complementarity constraints in the presence of linear side constraints. For this problem, we developed approximations much tighter than those introduced in earlier literature. Under certain technical conditions, we developed a cancel-and-relax procedure that avoid introducing extra variables while still producing a strong approximation. We generalized this procedure to simultaneous convexification of bilinear expressions. Second, we considered an application of robust optimization in network interdiction. The extension of the cancel-and-relax procedure described above allowed us to develop new valid inequalities for this problem. These inequalities help solve problem instances that were previously intractable using mixed-integer formulations. Third, for cardinality constrained problems, we developed a simple and fast way to separate a point with too many non-zeros from the feasible region. Our procedure generalizes many known inequalities and yields structural insights into the structure of these inequalities. We also considered the cardinality requirement with a side constraint that the point must be in a unit norm ball. Problems of this sort are common in parameter estimation. We developed new approximations for such problems. These relaxations generalize existing ones in the literature. Our numerical computations show that they obtain significantly closer estimates than previous relaxations of the maximum variance of point sets along directions that have a sparse support. Fourth, we consider nonlinear sets that generalize the structure in complementarity and cardinality problems. In this area, we developed new ways to approximate products of variables when the variables and the products have bounds. We also considered products of variables where all the variables have the same bounds. Similar results were also obtained for various generalizations. 


The results from our work should help improve the state-of-the-art for solving complementarity and cardinality problems, which have many varied applications. Our results on the relaxations of products of variables have utility for global optimization solvers in general. Our results show new ways of relaxing robust optimization problems and network interdiction problems in particular. The impact on society will be via improved solutions to data analysis problems. For example, sparse PCA, a problem for which we provide better approximations, has applications in financial and biological data analysis. Further, solutions to network interdiction problems can help us develop better strategies to control spreading of diseases and counteract terrorism.
